title: 111_hr2268
content: The "Internet Gambling Regulation and Tax Enforcement Act of 2009" is introduced, amending the 1986 Code to impose a tax on internet gambling and require licensee information reporting. This includes the imposition of an internet gambling license fee and record-keeping requirements. The Internet Gambling Regulation and Tax Enforcement Act of 2009 introduces a federal fee for internet gambling licensees, requiring a two percent fee on customer deposits monthly. Licensees are responsible for the fee, which cannot be deducted from deposits. The Internet Gambling Regulation and Tax Enforcement Act of 2009 imposes a fee on internet gambling licensees for customer deposits. Deposits made for unauthorized bets are subject to a 50 percent fee, due monthly. The Internet Gambling Regulation and Tax Enforcement Act of 2009 requires fees on internet gambling licensees for customer deposits, due monthly. Amounts paid as fees are deposited in the Treasury's general fund. Administrative provisions apply, subject to regulations by the Secretary. The Internet Gambling Regulation and Tax Enforcement Act of 2009 mandates record-keeping for fee liability, with daily deposit records required. Additionally, a new section on information returns related to internet gambling is added. Every licensee or person engaged in accepting bets must provide required information to the Secretary and maintain appropriate records as per regulations. This includes the name, address, and TIN of the licensee or person. The licensee or person accepting bets must provide the Secretary with information on bettors, including their name, address, TIN, gross winnings, wagers, losses, net Internet gambling winnings, tax withheld, account balances, and deposits/withdrawals for the calendar year. Every person required to make a return under subsection (a) must provide a written statement to individuals who placed bets or wagers, including the contact information and details needed for the return. This statement should be given to the individual by January 31 of the following year. The term 'net Internet gambling winnings' refers to gross winnings from online wagers with a licensed entity, minus the amounts wagered. Definitions for 'Internet' and 'wager' are based on specific terms in the US Code. The table of sections for internet gambling is amended to include returns relating to internet gambling. The amendments apply to bets placed after the enactment of the Act. Withholding from certain gambling winnings is addressed in Section 3. Section 3 of the Act addresses withholding from certain gambling winnings, specifically focusing on net Internet gambling winnings. The effective date for this amendment is for bets or wagers placed after the enactment of the Act. The Act amends tax laws to include taxation on winnings from Internet gambling with licensed entities and exempts certain gambling winnings from taxation. The Act amends tax laws to include taxation on Internet gambling winnings from licensed entities, exempts certain winnings from taxation, and specifies the withholding of tax on nonresident alien individuals for wagers placed over the Internet. The Act amends tax laws to include taxation on Internet gambling winnings from licensed entities, exempts certain winnings from taxation, and specifies the withholding of tax on nonresident alien individuals for wagers placed over the Internet. Section 4404 is amended to specify that items must be placed within the United States or any Commonwealth, territory, or possession by a United States citizen or resident.
